articles.headline: U.N. Visit Will Set Back a Push to Isolate Iran
articles.snippet: Despite American-led efforts to marginalize Iran, Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, plans to attend the annual meeting of the Nonaligned Movement being held there.
articles.abstract: Despite American-led efforts to marginalize Iran, Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, plans to attend the annual meeting of the Nonaligned Movement being held there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Efforts led by the United States and Israel to isolate Iran suffered a setback on Wednesday when the United Nations announced that Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, would join officials from 120 countries in Tehran next week for a summit meeting that Iran has trumpeted as a vindication of its defiance and enduring importance in world affairs.

articles.headline: In Google’s Inner Circle, a Falling Number of Women
articles.snippet: The search giant’s efforts to recruit and promote more women have resulted in more hires, but not in the executive offices.
articles.abstract: The search giant’s efforts to recruit and promote more women have resulted in more hires, but not in the executive offices.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — At Google, data is king. Now the company is using data to figure out if it can anoint a few queens.

articles.headline: Many at Fed Ready to Act if Necessary
articles.snippet: Minutes of the most recent policy meeting are likely to solidify expectations that the central bank will introduce new measures this fall.
articles.abstract: Minutes of the most recent policy meeting are likely to solidify expectations that the central bank will introduce new measures this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many Federal Reserve officials at their most recent policy meeting pushed for further actions to support the economy if the recovery failed to strengthen over the summer, an official account released on Wednesday showed.

articles.headline: Changes to Money Market Funds Stall
articles.snippet: Attempts to make sweeping changes to money-market mutual funds, which played a destabilizing role in the 2008 financial crisis, have been derailed.
articles.abstract: Attempts to make sweeping changes to money-market mutual funds, which played a destabilizing role in the 2008 financial crisis, have been derailed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attempts to make sweeping changes to a popular type of mutual fund that played a central role in the 2008 financial crisis have been derailed.

articles.headline: Signs of Revival, Slight but Sure, for Home Sales
articles.snippet: Sales of existing homes were up in July, continuing a trend of several months that real estate agents said was good news for the housing market.
articles.abstract: Sales of existing homes were up in July, continuing a trend of several months that real estate agents said was good news for the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Analysts are hailing the beginnings of a recovery in the nation’s housing market. But to beleaguered homeowners, it will not feel like much of one for many months to come.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Ties to Obama Aided in Access for Big Utility
articles.snippet: The Illinois-based energy producer Exelon Corporation has sometimes benefited from close ties with the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The Illinois-based energy producer Exelon Corporation has sometimes benefited from close ties with the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in the Obama administration, a lobbyist for the Illinois-based energy producer Exelon Corporation proudly called it “the president’s utility.” And it was not just because it delivers power to Barack Obama’s Hyde Park neighborhood in Chicago.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Techies Fight to Save a Popular but Illegal Haven
articles.snippet: A cavernous California warehouse that serves as an informal office building for the tech-enamored doesn’t comply with city regulations. But no one, including the city, wants to close it.
articles.abstract: A cavernous California warehouse that serves as an informal office building for the tech-enamored doesn’t comply with city regulations. But no one, including the city, wants to close it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Hacker Dojo is equal parts shared office, lecture hall and after-hours salon for a variety of tinkerers, software coders and entrepreneurs who intend to reinvent the future. The idea for Pinterest was cooked up here. The makers of Pebble watches used the space as their West Coast headquarters. Today, however, it is threatened with extinction. City officials in Mountain View have ordered Hacker Dojo to comply with city regulations for offices or move out.

articles.headline: Tiny Hawaiian Island Will See if New Owner Tilts at Windmills
articles.snippet: Larry Ellison, a technology billionaire, has bought the island for an undisclosed price. What he plans to do with the beautiful-yet-divided place is anyone’s guess.
articles.abstract: Larry Ellison, a technology billionaire, has bought the island for an undisclosed price. What he plans to do with the beautiful-yet-divided place is anyone’s guess.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANAI CITY, Hawaii — Lanai should be the very picture of tropical tranquillity, the kind of Pacific island where Gilligan set ground. Just 3,135 people live on its 141 square miles. There are no traffic lights, movie theaters or bakeries. There is just one gas station and three main roads. It is ringed with vast and empty beaches, accessible only by four-wheel drive. A visitor can roam its hills for hours without encountering another living being.

articles.headline: In Poll, Obama Is Given Trust Over Medicare
articles.snippet: New polls show that Medicare ranks as the third most crucial issue to likely voters in Florida, Ohio and Wisconsin, and that more respondents in each state trust President Obama to manage the program.
articles.abstract: New polls show that Medicare ranks as the third most crucial issue to likely voters in Florida, Ohio and Wisconsin, and that more respondents in each state trust President Obama to manage the program.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Romney-Ryan proposal to reshape Medicare by giving future beneficiaries fixed amounts of money to buy health coverage is deeply unpopular in Florida, Ohio and Wisconsin, according to new polls that found that more likely voters in each state trust President Obama to handle Medicare.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Dalia Sussman
